description: Marek Halden is appointed Head of the Central Oversight Directorate, tasked with unifying fragmented state infrastructure under a single framework for system-wide coordination.
Initial pilot testing of the Behavioral Compliance Index (BCI) begins in five regions, focusing on spending habits, travel patterns, and digital activity to generate early behavioral scoring models.
The BCI expands quietly through data-sharing agreements with telecoms, retailers, and transit providers. Halden signs off on adaptive algorithms to integrate personal and commercial data streams.
A high-level Council session ends in disagreement over expanding predictive scoring. Halden is granted provisional authority to reallocate discretionary system funding without oversight.
Halden restructures data access permissions, centralizing all BCI enforcement-related data under the Oversight Directorate. Other departments lose real-time visibility into behavioral flags.
An audio clip allegedly featuring Halden criticizing the Directorate circulates on encrypted message boards. The recording is not addressed by officials. Digital trace analysis is inconclusive.
A silent update to the BCI modifies how borderline behavior is interpreted, increasing flag sensitivity in low-compliance zones. The changes are applied directly from Halden's secure terminal.
A review reveals that hundreds of flagged individuals have disappeared from active watchlists. System logs point to inconsistent archival rules, but no formal investigation is launched.
Halden fails to attend a scheduled internal audit review. Security footage shows him entering Tower 9 the previous evening; no activity is recorded after 23:10.
Marek Halden is found dead in his residence-office in Tower 9. There are no signs of struggle. An initial assessment cites cardiac arrest as the cause of death.
Toxicology results reveal traces of a sedative used in psychiatric treatment. No criminal inquiry is opened. The medical report is sealed by directive from the Council’s internal health unit.
Authorities announce the death of Marek Halden in a one-paragraph statement. No cause is given. No interim replacement is named.
Multiple automated systems experience failures due to Halden’s exclusive access credentials. BCI subsystems enter fallback mode, triggering widespread delays and irregular scoring behavior.
